TopicTitle: has anyone tried to build a Roton

Articles.Content:
Greets to all,

 

Just a quick question from a noob who is playing the demo version.

 

Has anyone tried to build a Roton type SSTO?

 

For those who don't remember (or were too young to know) Roton was a somewhat bizarre, er I mean different SSTO proposal in the late 90s early 21st century. See Wikipedia for details .

 

Loosely described as a helicopter to orbit the Roton used tip mounted rockets (or jet engines) to lift itself on a giant helicopter rotor. When the vehicle reached altitudes when the rotors stopped being efficient the rocket motors pointed mostly down while continuing to turn the rotors, which now switched to powering an awesome turbo pump that would provide pressure for a super big rocket engine at the roton's base.

 

Sounds crazy, but just maybe in the Kerbal-verse it could work. Anyone tried or willing to try?

 

As I said I am a noob and I am using the demo version so I can't.

 

Take care and have fun. May your rockets go exactly where you want them to go.

 

Regards

Orc

The tip mounted engine rotor has been done many times, tilting those rotors and engines to bring them into vertical mode could be done with Infernal Robotics mod, and boosting from say 20km, which might be the highest lift powered flight ceiling could be done with about 1500ms of dV which isn't too hard. However the wingtip engines would need to be jets which would not be any use for further vertical ascent, and it would need to switch to full rocket mode. The tip engines could be Rapiers (Sabre Analogues) which can switch from jet to rocket. I think it could be done. I doubt it would be as efficient as an ordinary spaceplane, a rotor stage recovery system would be much more interesting as it does not involve re-igniting the booster engine.

@pandoras kitten May have done the best one: http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/101715-rotary-winged-vtol-rocket-with-free-spinning-center-section-inspired-by-roton-rotary-amp-triebflugel/

Ahh, the Roton. I always thought it was an interesting idea back then. However if I remember correctly, and I believe the web agrees with me: the Roton launched like a conventional rocket. It used the rotor system for landing and incorporated tip jets so the pilot could touch down under power instead of just autorotating.

During launch and in orbit the rotor blades were folded flat against the rockets fuselage. The blades were only extended during reentry to help with stability and to start them spinning up. 

A totally awesome completely Kerbal design from the amazing 1990's.
